title: Brazilian Silicon Valley
text:
Brazilian Silicon Valley is a term commonly applied to the region of <a href="Campinas">Campinas</a> and in southern region this term is applied for <a href="Florian%C3%B3polis">Florianópolis</a> city, <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a> because of its similarity to the 'original' <a href="Silicon%20Valley">Silicon Valley</a>, located in <a href="California">California</a> in the <a href="United%20States">USA</a>.
Characteristics.
Campinas has gained this distinction because it has several comparable features, such as:
History.
Until the 1970s, the Campinas region had few industries and had an <a href="Economic%20system">economy</a> based on <a href="agriculture">agriculture</a> and in the services and <a href="commerce">commerce</a> sectors. With the foundation of UNICAMP and the ready availability of high-quality <a href="researcher">researcher</a>s, <a href="engineer">engineer</a>s and <a href="student">student</a>s focused on <a href="physics">physics</a>, <a href="electrical%20engineering">electrical engineering</a>, <a href="computer%20sciences">computer sciences</a>, <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, <a href="mechanical%20engineering">mechanical engineering</a>, etc., a number of high-tech companies started to establish their industrial plants and <a href="R%26amp%3BD">R&D</a> labs nearby, such as <a href="IBM">IBM</a>. The municipality of Campinas and those surrounding it began to foster actively the growth of this new area, and the CIATEC I and II (<a href="Companhia%20de%20Desenvolvimento%20do%20P%C3%B3lo%20de%20Alta%20Tecnologia%20de%20Campinas">Companhia de Desenvolvimento do Pólo de Alta Tecnologia de Campinas</a>) industrial zones were established around the university campus, in the subdistrict of <a href="Bar%C3%A3o%20Geraldo">Barão Geraldo</a>. The Center for Research and Development (CPqD) set up by <a href="Telebras">Telebras</a>, a state holding for the <a href="telecommunications">telecommunications</a> industry in Brazil, which had grown enormously under the military regime umbrella, was the second boost to Campinas Silicon Valley. A law was passed by the Federal government, protecting Brazilian-made technology against imports, and this resulted in further growth. Together with UNICAMP researchers a number of pioneering developments occurred in the brand-new areas of <a href="laser">laser</a>s, <a href="fiber%20optics">fiber optics</a>, <a href="digital%20telephony">digital telephony</a>, <a href="computer">computer</a> technology, <a href="software">software</a> development, and so on. In addition, the <a href="Petrobras">Petrobras</a> state-owned <a href="Petroleum">oil</a> giant was starting to develop a long range oil exploration program with the aim of making Brazil independent of oil imports, a policy also started by the military for strategic and economic reasons (the <a href="1979%20energy%20crisis">oil shock</a> had deeply affected the country), and UNICAMP was one of the leading research universities to participate. In this respect, UNICAMP's open philosophy of collaboration with the private sector (unheard of in Brazil until that time), established by his visionary founder and first rector, Dr. <a href="Zeferino%20Vaz">Zeferino Vaz</a>, prepared the way for a unique synergy between industry and university.
